answers.author: Brian Halverson
answers.text:
Look at your alumni network, and the university career center (if your college has its own that is even better).  Getting a referal from someone already working for the City was a big help in landing my first job after getting my MPA. 
However, I did spend a lot of time looking at "League of Cities" type websites, this site, and a lot of individual state, county, and city websites.   You might also consider looking at consulting firm websites.  
I know its ubertedious, but I recommend customizing your resume and cover letter to each position you apply for.  I also recommend calling the hiring department and trying to get in touch with the people you will be working for/with.  This gives you a chance to learn about the position and make a good first impression. 
Also don't be to picky.  I am a Sr. Management Analyst for the Solid Waste Management Department here in San Antonio, but when I first heard about the position I was somewhat less enthusiastic.  I was hoping to land an Assistant to the City Manager type position, or something in the budget office.  However, I was hired to this position and I love it!  The people, culture, and work are all excellent.  What's more, I still get to work on the budget and with department and city management. 
Best of luck to you Anbar!

answers.author: Alexandra Sheeks
answers.text:
Check out the ICMA website and local government associations in individual states (I'm familiar with the League of California Cities and the Association of Washington Cities).  Check out NeoGov as well - many cities subscribe to this service for job posting.
Ditto what Brian said.  Look outside the box at cities, counties, and special districts.  Also, be patient!  I've seen so many people anxious to get high-ranking titles right out of grad school.  In this economy, that's not realistic.  I had to work over 10 years up through the ranks, starting as a customer service rep for a city water billing department, before I was able to become a management analyst and finally an assistant to the CM.  It might sound old-fashioned, but you do have to pay your dues.  Plus, you learn a lot by doing the "grunt" work.
Good luck and have fun!

answers.author: Robert Carty
answers.text:
Ditto to Brian's and Alex's comments. I wouldn't underestimate the power of networking either, and engaging with professionals in the field in states where you'd like to work. Also check with your alumni network for people in the profession.  If your finances allow you to join a state or national professional association that is a good resume booster that shows you are serious about your profession.

answers.author: Peni Basalusalu
answers.text:
Ditto to all the points given above.  I graduated in 03 with my MPA and started as a part-time Rec Leader in a Parks and Rec Dept, while looking for a full-time gig.  I worked my tail off and demonstrated what I could bring to the dept and 3 months into doing that, they offered me a full-time position as an Analyst.  Ironically, I am down to ground zero again after facing lay-offs last December from being a Program Manager.  However, I am volunteering in a CM's office and getting valubel work done and keeping my resume updated while I continue to look for work.  Don't let the economic climate be a hinderence to your search.  Do anything anywhere and you never know what it will bring you.  Networking with your alumni orgnization is indeed a great tool, as was indicated.  Good luck to you.

author: Anbar Ahmed
text:
Hello all,
I just recently graduated with my MPA and am looking for a job in the public sector.  I have started applying to jobs.  At present, I have been going to local municipalities websites to look for open positions.  Are there resources that anyone can recommend that I should check out?  I am currently in Arizona but would have no problem with relocating.  Any advice would be greatly appreciated.  Thanks so much!
